Post.title: migrate mysql data
Post._content:
# Migrate MySQL Data
## Background
Mysql is installed in root directory, and the data is stored in `/var/lib/mysql` directory.
When the root directory is not sufficient for the data.
we need to migrate the data to another directory.
```bash
mysql --version 
mysql  Ver 8.0.41-0ubuntu0.20.04.1 for Linux on x86_64 ((Ubuntu))
```

## Modify the mysql configuration file
First stop the mysql service.
```bash
sudo systemctl stop mysql
```

Then create a new directory for the mysql data.
The config file is located in `/etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf` file.

```bash
vim /etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf
```
Then add or overwrite the following lines to the file.
```bash
datadir=/home/mysql/mysql
socket=/home/mysql/mysql/mysql.sock

log-error=/home/mysql/log/mysqld.log
pid-file=/home/mysql/run/mysqld/mysqld.pid
```
## Create the new directory
```bash
sudo mkdir -p /home/mysql/mysql
sudo mkdir -p /home/mysql/log
touch /home/mysql/log/mysqld.log
sudo mkdir -p /home/mysql/run/mysqld
```

## Change the ownership
```bash
cp -ar /var/lib/mysql/ /home/mysql/mysql/
sudo chown -R mysql:mysql /home/mysql
sudo chmod 777 /home/mysql
```

## Change the AppArmor configuration
```bash
sudo vim /etc/apparmor.d/usr.sbin.mysqld
# add this line at the end of the file
alias /var/lib/mysql/ -> /home/mysql/,
# then restart
systemctl restart apparmor
```

## Start the mysql service
```bash
sudo systemctl start mysql
# delete the old files
rm -rf /var/lib/mysql
```

# Migrate MySQL Data
## Background
Mysql is installed in root directory, and the data is stored in `/var/lib/mysql` directory.
When the root directory is not sufficient for the data.
we need to migrate the data to another directory.
```bash

mysql  Ver 8.0.41-0ubuntu0.20.04.1 for Linux on x86_64 ((Ubuntu))
```

## Modify the mysql configuration file
First stop the mysql service.
```bash
sudo systemctl stop mysql
```

Then create a new directory for the mysql data.
The config file is located in `/etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf` file.

```bash
vim /etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf
```
Then add or overwrite the following lines to the file.
```bash
datadir=/home/mysql/mysql
socket=/home/mysql/mysql/mysql.sock

log-error=/home/mysql/log/mysqld.log
pid-file=/home/mysql/run/mysqld/mysqld.pid
```
## Create the new directory
```bash
sudo mkdir -p /home/mysql/mysql
sudo mkdir -p /home/mysql/log
touch /home/mysql/log/mysqld.log
sudo mkdir -p /home/mysql/run/mysqld
```

## Change the ownership
```bash
cp -ar /var/lib/mysql/ /home/mysql/mysql/
sudo chown -R mysql:mysql /home/mysql
sudo chmod 777 /home/mysql
```

## Change the AppArmor configuration
```bash
sudo vim /etc/apparmor.d/usr.sbin.mysqld
# add this line at the end of the file
alias /var/lib/mysql/ -> /home/mysql/,
# then restart
systemctl restart apparmor
```

## Start the mysql service
```bash
sudo systemctl start mysql
# delete the old files
rm -rf /var/lib/mysql
```

Post.title: hello vision pro
Post._content: # Vision Os Development Start with the [official document vision os path](https://developer.apple.com/visionos/pathway/) and start the journey of vision os development. ## Requirements As the official notes that the development needs `frameworks like SwiftUI, UIKit, RealityKit, and ARKit` ## Cretate a new project ### Open Xcode and create a new project, select the `visionOS` template, and select `App` as the template. ### Then start the project, and select the `visionOS` simulator as the target device. ## The project structure The HelloVisionOsApp is the main entry point of the app ```swift import SwiftUI @main struct MyApp: App { var body: some Scene { WindowGroup { ContentView() } } } ``` The Hierarchy of the app is like this: ```swift MyApp ├── WindowGroup │ └── ContentView │ ├── Text │ └── Button │ └── Text ``` The ContentView is the main view ```swift import SwiftUI import RealityKit struct ContentView: View { var body: some View { VStack { Text("Hello World") } } } ``` So the app is finished, and you can run it on the simulator. ### Summary The vision os development is based on the SwiftUI, so you need to learn the SwiftUI first, and then you can start the vision os development. - [SwiftUI](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftui/) - [VisionOS](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/visionos/creating-your-first-visionos-app) The Demo is simple and I remove the immersive part which will be the next post. #### The Demo [The Demo](https://github.com/little-stoner/VisionOs) project

Post.content:
Vision Os Development

Start with the official document vision os path and start the journey of vision os development.

Requirements

As the official notes that the development needs frameworks like SwiftUI, UIKit, RealityKit, and ARKit

Cretate a new project

Open Xcode and create a new project, select the visionOS template, and select App as the template.

Then start the project, and select the visionOS simulator as the target device.

The project structure

The HelloVisionOsApp is the main entry point of the app

The Hierarchy of the app is like this:

The ContentView is the main view

So the app is finished, and you can run it on the simulator.

Summary

The vision os development is based on the SwiftUI, so you need to learn the SwiftUI first, and then you can start the vision os development.

  • SwiftUI
  • VisionOS

The Demo is simple and I remove the immersive part which will be the next post.

The Demo

The Demo project

Post.title: learn swift ui
Post.content:
Learn SwiftUI

Text

Text is like text tag in HTML.
It is used to display text on the screen.
It can be used to display text in different styles, such as bold, italic, and underline.

Symbols

Symbols are like icons in HTML.

Label

To use both text and symbol to represent a single element.

Control

Control is interactive elements that allow users to interact with the app.

Image

Image is just like image tag in HTML.

Shape

Shape provides several common shapes.

Scale views

View layout that adapts to the font styles, Dynamic Type, and varying string lengths.

Layering content

The iphone message overlay effect

Hide A View

Hide a view is the way in vue v-if

Stacks

Stacks align the element in its.
HStack, VStack, ZStack

Summary

swift ui is more like a combination of HTML and CSS.
It is declarative and reactive kind of like vue.
It is easy to use and understand.

It is easy to use and understand.

Post.title: swift ui scene
Post.content:
SwiftUI Scene

The App return a Scene object.
The Scene return the primary scene WidnowGroup.
The WindowGroup return a TabView object.
The TabView return two views, ContentView and SettingsView.
The TabItem is used to set the text and icon of the tab.

Add Another WindowGroup

Seems like the new WindowGroup does not influence the primary windowGroup.
Post.more:
